ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:
Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I learned about historical case studies of social change and read a lot of classic texts of politics and power.
I learned about historical grand strategies, across militaries, politics, and social movements.
Theories of grand strategy (as it applies to war, politics, and social movements), and case studies where grand strategic decisions were particularly salient

The syllabus of this course is phenomenal and serves as a very robust introduction to strategy across time periods and contexts. I read a variety of 'classic' texts and authors, such as Thucydides, Machiavelli, Sun Tzu, etc. in addition to more contemporary articles and case study-specific literature. The discussion format of this class also allowed us to develop skills in speaking/discussing areas of interest in terms of strategy.

Analyzing traditional pieces on strategy in wars, republics, and social movements; working in a group setting to understand and piece together ideas of strategy; connecting strategic ideas across different contexts

I likely would not have read most of the course readings if I did not take Grand Strategy (thucydides, clausewitz, machiavelli, etc). However, these are texts that are referenced in political decision-making. I now have a better grasp on these texts and could engage in a conversation about them. Strategy is also a process that is applicable in most fields, from the military to healthcare efficacy to political campaigns, so it is helpful to have a grounding in these readings.
I learned the basic foundations of grand strategy and read a lot of classical and modern texts

I had never read any of the texts we engaged. I even learned new things about the Civil Rights movement, which I thought I knew well, and the global context it existed within. Every week presented a new set of considerations one may consider using or being used in opposition to them when developing a strategy.

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Grand Strategy is a good program. The emphasis on political theory was a little much for me and I thought the first half of the semester went pretty slowly. I also thought that the guest lecture/Q&A style of the first half of the semester was not very interesting.
I really love the application in case studies at the end of the course, drawing together all of the material and applying the other readings and frameworks.

Well taught course, but the post-small group discussion posts were not helpful.  They detracted from the conversation as students were focused more on note taking and the write up than engaging with each other.

No weaknesses. This course was engaging, organized, and fulfilling. I really enjoyed the readings and thought the professors worked hard to create a welcoming class environment. I just wish we got feedback on our writing earlier on in the semester.

I overall felt that the course format and assignments fit the objectives/subject matter very well and allowed us to engage effectively with themes in grand strategy. However, I would have several proposals for changes to the syllabus. There were very few authors of color and also other notable works of 'strategy' that were not on the syllabus; for instance, it was mentioned in class that Lenin and other leftist thinkers were grand strategists in their own right, yet such authors were not included in our readings. I do think, though, that the case studies chosen for the last few weeks of class were fitting and that the overall organization of the material (starting with military strategy, moving into political strategy/leadership, and ending with social movements) was effective.

Strengths: amazing professors, interesting readings, perceptive classmates
Weaknesses: the readings can sometimes be long; Mondays are packed with class and events (sometimes 2:30pm-7pm straight); the group work can be annoying if some people fail to participate

A strength of the class is the weekly guest speakers. The guest speakers are experts in their field and it is great to engage with them in a smaller setting; they offer additional insight into that week's readings and their respective work. A weakness is the workload. I'm not sure if this is usually an assignment, or if it was only added during the pandemic, but each week students met in small groups and wrote a short group essay (~500-700 words) about their thoughts/discussion on that week's readings. This assignment was on top of the weekly individual reading responses. The course requires high engagement, which is fine, but it felt excessive to participate in discussions with the entire class, small group, and guest speaker and also write an individual and group reading response each week. Also, the Social Movements and Social Change and Case Studies in U.S. History units could include readings from more progressive leaders.

The readings are definitely a strength of the course, I left feeling like a learned a lot of framing/important theoretical background for the rest of my intellectual pursuits. The class would obviously be more engaging in person, but Prof. Gage and Brenes did an excellent job facilitating very interesting discussions virtually. The class could perhaps be improved by cutting the time we spend writing responses in a small group to more organized full-group time, or interaction with the practitioners.

Prof Gage and Brenes are very accessible  whenever you need help, you can easily contact them during office hours. They made a good effort to make zoom interesting, too -- we had a guest speaker lead the first part of class and then a group.

The instructor-led discussion followed by a chance to break into groups and develop a response to the weekly prompts worked really well. The events were we were able to meet practitioners and learn a bit more about there experiences were great. The readings were great at helping up consider what strategy looks like at different levels.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Everything was on Zoom, which was even more of a drag than usual because class met on Mondays and we would also frequently have Monday guest speakers/events, which meant more than 3 hours on GS related Zoom in a day.
The small group discussions were very effective, and they allowed students the opportunity to get to know each other more and hash out less decisive opinions.
I thought the unique discussion format for this course (guest speakers followed by smaller discussion groups) worked quite well to facilitate student learning during a Zoom semester.

Having guest speaker events, webinars, etc. on Monday nights immediately after our class became very exhausting, and I know that this feeling was shared among many peers in class. In-person, I think this would be very different (we could move from our classroom to a dinner with a speaker, etc., and it would overall be more engaging) but virtually it was rather draining to have two hours of virtual class followed immediately by 2-3 more hours on Zoom with speakers, events, etc. I think events should have been spaced out a bit more across the week given the virtual format.

The events worked well for us to get a chance to learn about the speakers and our future lecturers. While there is no substitute for being able to sit down and share a good old-fashioned meal with someone, the Grubhub vouchers added a sense of occasion.

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Good class. There's a ton of reading, so if you like doing readings, it will be a good fit. Hoping the second half of the class is more engaging and interesting than the first, which spent too much time on political theory and a lecture/Q&A style of seminar.

Absolutely! This class was a fascinating way to study history, meet incredible people (the professors, other students, guest speakers), and think about large issues with other people who are inspired and driven.
Yes, but don't be surprised when the classics of grand strategy (warfare, diplomacy, statecraft) are pushed aside for more socially-oriented discussions.
If you get accepted to this course, take it. It is a special program and it will be integral to your intellectual and personal development.

Yes! I already have recommended it and will continue to do so because I strongly feel that more students interested in community organizing, advocacy, social movements, and transformative/radical politics should take Grand Strategy. This program in the past has had a reputation of being conservative and/or focused on military strategy, and while military-related topics are certainly covered in introducing strategy/related themes, my own experience in this course has been overwhelmingly positive and engaging even given that the military is not at all my area of interest. Professor Gage and Professor Brenes have truly done a phenomenal job of including topics such as political strategy, organizing, social movements and social change, etc.  for instance, a great deal of time in class is spent discussing the slavery abolition movement, the civil rights movement, etc. No matter your political ideology or interests, I think any student hoping to make change  be it through politics/policy, organizing, or any other means  can gain a great deal from this class. I encourage anyone even remotely interested in strategy to apply.

YES for sure! I loved my classmates and hearing what they had to say, and I really appreciated the wide variety of lenses through which we analyzed strategy: wars, republics, and social movements. It was interesting to see the connections between the strategies of these three, and the course allowed us to read a lot of fundamental pieces that are addressed in other classes (e.g., Alinsky, Thucydides, Federalist Papers, etc.). Highly recommend!
This course attracts students from all corners of campus, so it's worthwhile to apply

If you can get in, I highly recommend it. GS gets a bad rep sometimes at Yale for being pre-professional, but depending on what you're looking for, you''ll get as much out of the class as you put in. The readings are excellent, and Prof. Gage has brought in interesting perspectives to the traditional cannon. I also really appreciated the opportunity to actually engage with and get to know the visiting practitioners.

Yes!! If you can get in, you have SO many opportunities to meet people, undertake a research project, and learn about a field that is being expanded beyond military strategy (although as someone who had no knowledge of military strategy, I learned a lot there, too)

I would definitely recommend this course. The readings and practitioners build out a sense of the history of global affairs and key considerations one must make when crafting grand strategy. The guest speakers who step in, the questions posed to students, and the questions answered by practitioners will advance your ability to pay attention to key variables when strategizing.

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.
comments: We also had a bunch of Zoom sessions with various intellectuals and public figures on Monday nights throughout the semester.
Virtual seminar with (almost) weekly events outside of the structured class time
Virtual and in-person office hours were available by appointment, and this course included many guest lectures and other virtual opportunities with speakers.
It was a synchronous virtual seminar that met once a week.
N/A
An additional mode of learning was near weekly virtual dinners and special events.

extras.title:
HIST 482J 01/PLSC 321 01/GLBL 342 01
        Studies in Grand Strategy I
